ABSTRACT

FILHO, Carlos Alberto da Silva. Silica nanoparticles as carriers of sodium dodecyl sulfate and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide for enhance d oil recovery . Rio de Janeiro, 2019. Dissertation (Master in Chemistry) ‚Äì Instituto de Qu√≠mica, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Rio de Janeiro , 2019

The objective of this work was to evaluate nanofluids composed of nanosilica with anionic surfactant (sodium dodecyl sulfate, SDS) or with cationic surfactant (cetyltrimethylammoniu m bromide CTAB), adsorbed on the nanoparticles surface to improve oil recovery and to allow a l ower adsorption of surfactants o n the surface of the reservoirs rock. TGA, FTIR, SEM and DLS analyzes were used to evaluate the characteristics of the systems obtained. The results indicated that the adsorption of the surfactant s on the surface of the silica nanoparticle was successful. Dynamic transport assays were performed by injecting the surfactants, nanoparticles and mixtures of the nanoparticles with the surfactants into a non-consolidated porous media consisting of sand. It was determined the impact of different parameters such as porosity, pressure and concentration of the injection flow, in the mobility of the different evaluated systems. For all the parameters mentioned above, the worst system was that containing the pu re CTAB, which showed a greater retention when compared to the other systems. However, this retention decreased when the silica nanoparticles were added, showing tha t the CTAB adsorption on the nanoparticle surface reduces the losses to the sand medium. Th e ability of the systems to improve the recovery factor through dynamic column tests was evaluated with two types of oil: pure vaseline and a mixture of 75% crude oi l and 25% heptane . The best recovery factors were obtained with systems composed of silica NP plus SDS, with 27% petroleum jelly and 34% additional oil recovery. Fo r the system with silica NP with CTAB, it was obtained a 29% additional recovery for vaseline and for the oil mixture the addional recovery was 43%. The nanoparticle systems with adsorbed surfactants on their surface were able to decrease the losses from adsorption of surfactant on the rock , especially those with CTAB. The systems also showed mobility in the unbound medium and were able to d eliver the surfactants at the water / oil interface, increasing the oil recovery factor.
